g.text: the upper boundary conditions are a TOA solar insolation (
and a solar zenith angle of 53°. The lower boundary con-
dition is a Lambertian surface with a spectrally flat albedo of 0.1. The
atmospheric thermodynamic conditions and water vapor and ozone
mixing ratios correspond to the Air Force Geophysics Laboratory
onto 458 vertical levels extending from the surface at 1011.4 hPa to
the effective top of the atmosphere at 0.0 hPa. This is the same atmo-
spheric profile used for the LBL calculations in RTMIP.
The first set of LBL calculations is based on HITRAN editions 2000
included methane lines up through the fourth polyad, or tetradecad
(icosad) and sixth (triacontad) polyads at ~7500 and 9000 cm
HITRAN 2012 data set added the eighth (pentacontakaipentad)
polyad has subsequently been measured in the laboratory (
has been included in the 2016 HITRAN edition. As of this writing,
still not fully implemented in the LBL code described below, and
therefore, we have not included it in our calculations.
The second set of LBL calculations is based on CH
properties fromcompilations of measurements of the Jovian planetary
were computed using the Voigt-Goody model following
) is the spectrally varying absorption coefficient at tem-
is the integrated methane amount per unit area (in
dependent ratio of the mean line spacing to Doppler line
tion, SFB is the dimensionless self-to-foreign broadening coefficient,
(iii) are available fromoptical measurements of Jovian planetary atmo-
, and we performed the calculations at these bounding values
) between 1.2 and 1.5, and we again performed the cal-
culations at these bounding values and the best fit value (
integrated these equations using the DQAGI numerical quadrature
routines from the SLATEC (Sandia, Los Alamos, Air Force Weapons
Laboratory Technical Exchange Committee) Fortran library (
We input the atmospheric profiles and HITRAN line databases
into an LBL radiative transfer code to calculate the vertically and spec-
trally resolved profiles of absorption optical depths summed over
. We used the Line-By-Line Radiative Transfer
) version 12.2 to perform these calculations for
HITRAN 2000, 2004, and 2008 and version 12.4 for HITRAN 2012.
The switch to the newer version was necessitated by the new line
mixing specification parameters starting in HITRAN 2012 (
treatments of the water vapor continuum in LBLRTM versions 12.2
We used a spectral resolution of
resolve 99% of the very narrow H
O absorption lines in the strato-
covering 98.6% of TOA insolation. The re-
sulting tables of absorption optical depth contain 3.2 × 10
intervals times 458 vertical levels and are therefore much too large
for practical calculations of radiative flux profiles. For this reason, we
constructed transmission weighted average optical depths for subse-
quent radiative calculations at a much lower spectral resolution of
inal high-resolution optical depth summed over H
, respectively. Then, the averaged optical depth was computed by
By construction, each averaged optical depth yields the same transmis-
sion through a given layer as the mean of the transmissions for the
high-resolution spectral intervals used in its calculation. Because of the
very large optical depths that can exceed 10
and its overtone bands in the near-
), the calculations in Eq. 6 require nonstandard numerical
precision. In standard single or double precision computer arithmetic,
the transmissions corresponding to these very large optical depths
will underflow and be set to zero. However, in quadruple precision
computer arithmetic, the smallest number that can be represented is

R E S E A R C H A R T I C L E
